title: If you’re under 34, you’ve not experienced a month of below average temperatures
text:
People enjoy warm weather on Bournemouth beach in Dorset in August (Picture: PA)

People under 34 have never experienced a month of below average global temperatures.

Every month, NASA publishes an estimate of global surface temperature change in the GISS Surface Temperature Analysis.

Records show that the last year to experience global annual temperatures below the 1951-1980 average was 1976.

This means that people younger than 43 have never lived through a year with below average temperatures.

Furthermore, the data also reveals that if you’re under 34 years old, you’ve never experienced a single month of below average global temperatures.

The last month to see below average temperatures was February 1985 and this was just the second month in six years.

Even if you are 65 years old and hitting retirement, 79% of your life has been spent in a world with above-average temperatures, analysis from The Guardian shows.

Those born in 1946 have spent 52% of their first 40 years in above-average temperatures, but those born in 1972 have lived 89% of their first 40 years in hotter temperatures than the 1951-1980 average.

The ‘Beast from the East’ hits Glasgow, Scotland on February 28, in Glasgow, Scotland (Picture: Getty Images)

Activists from Extinction Rebellion participate in a disco protest where they temporarily played dead at the Bourke Street mall in Melbourne, Australia, 11 October 2019 (Picture: EPA)

The statistics follow the news that July 2019 was the hottest month on record, according to the 140 years of data kept by the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Professor Richard Allan, a professor of climate science at the University of Reading, said it was ‘our fault’ the planet was heating up.

He said: ‘Months which break the global temperature record, such as July 2016 and June and July 2019, are now the expectation rather than a surprise since this is entirely consistent with the increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide caused by human activities.

‘Just as one swallow does not make a summer, one record month does not tell us much on its own since the fickle nature of weather systems and the slow sloshing about of the ocean can sometimes temporarily warm or cool the planet.

‘However, the clustering of recent record hot years and months, the longer-term warming trend and our understanding of the physics of the atmosphere and oceans confirms that our climate is heating up, it’s our fault and the way to stop this is to reduce and begin removing emissions of greenhouse gases.’

Extinction Rebellion activists began two weeks of climate change protests on Monday, with more than 1,000 activists already arrested just four days in.

Protesters blocked access to the BBC’s headquarters today, with staff reportedly unable to enter or leave through the main entrance.

Around 50 people were arrested at London City Airport yesterday, where activists attempted a ‘Hong Kong-style occupation of the terminal building’ with hundreds blocking the main entrance.

Police officers arrest an activist at London City Airport during the fourth day of demonstrations by the climate change action group Extinction Rebellion, in London, on October 10, 2019 (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Climate activists protest at the BBC offices during the fifth day of demonstrations by the climate change action group Extinction Rebellion, in London, on October 11, 2019 (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Some climbed onto the terminal roof and glued themselves to the entrance of the Docklands Light Railway (DLR) station, while one man climbed on top of a British Airways plane.

GP Dr Chris Newman, 38, from North London, attended the protest wearing a stethoscope and scrubs and told Metro.co.uk that we are running out of time.

He said: ‘I’m a GP, I have a duty to look after the health of the public and its very clear that the way this county is going, that people are going to be suffering the horrendous consequences of climate change and ecological destruction.

‘This includes heat, disease, violence and war. It could be 80 years, it could be 50 years, it could be 20 years, and we’re going to be on the front line.’

He added: ‘As a doctor, I’m proud to be part of Extinction Rebellion. This is a public health intervention.

‘Many of my colleagues have been here, many have been arrested.

‘We’ve tried other means, telling the government what we think they should do – and they haven’t done it.’
